titleStmt.title: A Relation of the sundry occurrences in Ireland from the fleet of ships set out by the adventurers of the additionall forces by sea. With the names of the ships, and the commanders of them, and their severall burdens, and number of men in every ship. Also the names of the commanders of the land-forces, under the command of the Right Honorable Robert Lord Brooke, all set out by the said adventurers, also a true copy, of most wicked verses written in forme of a ballad, defying the English, being found in a rebels pocket, and sent among other papers to the adventurers. Hereunto is added, the true copy of a letter sent from Colonell Goring to his Majesty, which letter was intercepted by the way, and now published.

Also the names of the commanders of the land-forces, under the command of the Right Honorable Robert Lord Brooke, all set out by the said adventurers, also a true copy, of most wicked verses written in forme of a ballad, defying the English, being found in a rebels pocket, and sent among other papers to the adventurers. Hereunto is added, the true copy of a letter sent from Colonell Goring to his Majesty, which letter was intercepted by the way, and now published.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A RELATION OF THE SVNDRY OCCVRRENCES IN IRELAND From the Fleet of Ships ≈øet out by the Adventurers of the Additionall Forces by SEA.
With the Names of the Ships, and the Commanders of them, and their ≈øeverall burdens, and number of Men in every Ship.
Al≈øo the Names of the Commanders of the Land-Forces, under the command of the Right Honorable Robert Lord Brooke, all ≈øet out by the ≈øaid Adventurers,
Al≈øo a true Copy, of mo≈øt wicked Ver≈øes written in forme of a Ballad, defying the Engli≈øh, being found in a Rebels pocket, and ≈øent among other papers to the Adventurers.
Hereunto is added, the true Copy of a Letter ≈øent from Colonell Goring to his Maje≈øty, which Letter was intercepted by the way, and now publi≈øhed.
LONDON, Printed by E. G. for Hen. Overton, 1642.

div.head: A Relation of the ≈øundry Occurrences in Ireland, from the Fleet of Ships ≈øet out by the Adventurers of the additionall Forces by Sea.
div.p: AFter a long pa≈ø≈øage from London we arrived the 10 of july la≈øt at Kin≈øale with 10 ≈øaile of our fleet, where the Right Honorable Alexander, Lord Forbes our Commander, next unto the Right Honorable Lord Brooke, received intelligence that the Town of Bandonbridge wherein were 7000 Engli≈øh Prote≈øtants was in great want of Amunition, and that the Lord Muskery (the chiefe Rebell) withall his Forces, intended within 5 or 6 dayes to ≈øet upon the ≈øaid Town, to take it and to put all the Engli≈øh to the Sword, ≈øuch is the rage malice and hatred of tho≈øe Rebells again≈øt them that they would not ≈øpare man woman nor hild. But by the good providence of Almighty God, we arived in the very rick of time to the great joy and comfort of the Engli≈øh, and to the terror of the Rebells, preventing them from their intended de≈øigne.

The Lord Forbes lo≈øt no time in the exerci≈øing of his men, and the 15 of Iuly with 800 Land and Seamen corragiou≈øly marched towards Bandon for the reliefe of it, and other Ca≈øtles thereabouts who were blockt up by the Rebells.

The inhabitants of Bandon upon ≈øight of the reliefe came unto them from the Parliament, and the Adventurers in the additional Forces by Sea for Ireland, with good ≈øtore of Amunition, as Muskets, Powder, Shot and other nece≈ø≈øaries were much revived, leaping for joy, and returned publick thanks to Almighty God for his great mercy and goodne≈ø≈øe to them, in ≈øending this ≈øupply in ≈øuch their great ≈øtraight and mi≈øery. Ma≈øter Peters our Mini≈øter preached at Bandon, much incouraging the Inhabitants.

The 16 of July the Lord Forbes with his 800 men, and 200 Foote and 70 Hor≈øe of Ban ‚Ä¢ on, marched from thence to cleere the Country of Rebells, that the Engli≈øh might reap and gather in their harve≈øt; As al≈øo for the reliefe of Raph Barry Ca≈øtle being from King fale as we marched about 25 Engli≈øh miles; and in our march we ≈øet upon an Engli≈øh Towne called Cloughnieilty, which the Rebels formerly took and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, which Town we took, and killed of the Rebels about 200, and had much pillage in it of Corne and Cattell, and there the Lord Forbes left 3. Companies of his men to guard the Towne and village.

From thence we marched with 700 men, and the troope of Hor≈øe for Raph Barry Ca≈øtle to relieve Ma≈øter Feak, and about 100 Engli≈øh that were blockt up. We furni≈øhed them with Men, Cowe, Hor≈øe, Sheep, Amunition, &c. And left them in good condition to defend them≈øelves again≈øt the Rebells, the Ca≈øtle being very ≈øtrong of it ≈øelfe, and lying within a mile of the Town of Ro≈ø≈øe.

When our Souldiers were at dinner, newes came that Generall Maccarte Tego
Downing, and ≈øome of Lord Muskery his Forces about 7000 Foote, and 300 Hor≈øe were falle upon our three Companies, left at Cloughnieilty, and that they were in great danger, whereupon the Lord Forbes together with his Captaine and Souldiers with more then ordinary valour, courage and re≈øolution, ha≈øtened to relieve them: and comming in ≈øight of the Rebels Army, and ≈øeeing two of our Colours playing in a little brea≈øt worke beleagured with 1000 Rebells about them; we marched up neer them, and gave five to one of our Feild Pieces of Ordnance, which made the Rebells retreate, whereby we re≈øcued two of our ≈øai ‚Ä¢ Companies, the third being Captaine Weldon an old Souldier, but over Adventurous and more relying upon his own valour, then hearkning to the advice of other Captaines to retreate, very valiantly ≈øet upon the Rebells, and after he had killed many of them in the battell was ≈ølaine him≈øelfe, together with about h ‚Ä¢ lfe his Company.

As ≈øoone as we had re≈øcued our two Companies, we fell upon the Rebels who were in faire order of battell with divers Colours flying, and after ≈øome fight with them, the Lord Forbes commanded to open to the right and left, and ≈øhot a piece of Ordinance at them, whereupon they run away and were ≈øo routed that we ≈ølew many of them upon our pur≈øuit, and following them ≈øo clo≈øe divers we forced into the Sea, others got into an Iland, ≈øome into Bogs and Mountaines, and it was miraculous, and the great mercy of God that ≈øo great a defeat, upon ≈øo many by ≈øo ≈ømall a number was wrought in ≈øo ≈øhort a time, and not one of our men lo≈øt, in this march we verily believe that there is 800 Rebels ≈ølaine, ≈øome thinke 12 or 500 and among≈øt them many of the cheife Rebels and Commanders were ≈ølaine in this Battell; the booty we took from the Rebels upon this defeate, was ‚Ä¢ 000 Sheep 200 Cowes, and 50 Hor≈øe and Armes where with we marched to Bandon, and their left the booty to relieve the Town. From Bandon we marched to Timoleage and burnt the Town and Abby, and from thence came to King≈øale, where we found two of our other Ships returned, which were ≈øent to guard the Coa≈øt, and to relieve Baltimore, and Ca≈øtle-Haven, where were about 4. or 500. Engli≈øh.

The Frigat Penington. Captaine Clark Commander hath done very good ≈øervice a Baltimore by a ≈øtratagem having taken 17. Rebels there, ≈øome were the principall of them one Captain Mac-Carte, Dermon and Clouke Tego Downing be≈øides ≈øome others worth 500. l. Per Annum (as we are informed) they offer to ≈øupply provi≈øions for our Fleet, and a good ran≈øom only to ≈øpare their lives, we are now Shipping our men abord and ≈øo going to Baltimore.

We are informed that Galloway is out in Rebellion again ≈øo it is intended that ≈øo ≈øoone as the Lord Forbes meets with the re≈øt of the Fleet, and is compleat, after he ≈øhall have releived ≈øome Ca≈øtles in the way, and cleered the Country. We ≈øhall endeavour to releive Galloway Ca≈øtle, and to ≈øet upon that Town if God pro≈øper us we hope to carry it.

It is reported that the L. Randelo, Lord Pre≈øident of Conaught, hath done great ≈øervice ≈øince the Rebellion, having got about 400 Engli≈øh, together at Atlon. And Ro≈øcoman and hath fired the Country, 20 or 40 miles about, and hath inriched his men with the ≈øpoyle taken from the Rebels, and upon a late ≈øupply of 2000. men from Dublin it is hoped he will cleere mo≈øt part of that provence of Conaught, and march to Galloway to joyn with our Sea and Land forces, to beleager the Town.

The Lord Forbes with the other Commanders intend to lo≈øe no time, but to doe their uttermo≈øt in helping to reduce the Rebels to their due obedience to his Maje≈øty, and the Crown of England, it being high time, their in≈øolencies, and cruelties were curbed, they commonly calling us Parliament dogs, and London Prenti≈øes, and ≈øay their commi≈ø≈øion for their Rebellion is better then ours, but we hope God will inable us to help to quell their impudent cruelty.

Two of our Fleet are gon to Duncannon Ca≈øtle and Dublin, to convoy ≈øome provi≈øions and to bring advice of the ≈øtate of the Country, the Lord Forbers is petioned from divers places for his aid and ≈øupply, his Lord≈øhip will give them the be≈øt aid he can one after another, we hope this Fleet will do much good to this bleeding Kingdom, and releive many poore drouping ≈øoules, and we hope our great Armies in Lemp≈øter, and Vl≈øter, will with Gods ble≈ø≈øing cleere tho≈øe parts, and march into Mon≈øter to cleere tho≈øe parts of the≈øe pro≈øidious Rebels, which he of his infinite mercy grant for the advancement of the Go≈øpell, and the good of all His Maje≈øties Dominions.

div.head: The names of Ships imployed by the Adventurers in the Additionall forces by Sea for Ireland from London.
The Commanders of the Land-Forces, ≈øet out by the Adventurers in the additionall Forces by Sea for Ireland, under the command of the Right Honourable Robert Lord Brook.

div.head: To the meere irreligious murderer William Srintleger, Head and Governour of this paganicall Engli≈øh Army in the Kingdome of Ireland.
div.p:
WHereas we the Peers and Nobles of Ireland have with mutuall minds con≈øented to ≈øtand for our religion (God helping) and to maintaine this warre as well in the beginning as to the end thereof, again≈øt you Prote≈øtants and Puritants; the cau≈øe is ju≈øt on our ≈øide, you wholly bent to extirpate us out of this Kingdome, our native ≈øoyle, and to draw us mi≈øtaken wretches, (our God and his Commandements de≈øpi≈øed) to puritani≈øme: and in ≈øo much as you alledge that we rebell again≈øt our King, (The Lord protect and ≈øave him and his excellent Lady by the grace of God Queen of England, Scotland, France, and Ireland, Defender of of the Faith, &c, and his royall Crown) we an≈øwer that his Maje≈øty well plea≈øed with the true information of things formerly ill con≈øtituted by the un≈øpeakable ignorance of the two never ≈øufficiently torment, Luther and Calvin, with the liberty of religion and ≈øafety of poore Ireland long ≈øunked in the bottomle≈ø≈øe debt of calamity by your means, now deemed to be exalted to the high a≈øcence of felicity: to the ≈øufficient proofe of the aforementioned premi≈øes, we wi≈øh your pre≈øence at an appointed time and place, either to ≈øhew your skilful experiment in martial di≈øcipline, or to avouch by a grant demon≈øtrated your favour with His Maje≈øty, which is ab≈øurd, con≈øidering your conwardize and defect of courage, & all hope bani≈øhed, Your
valour in de≈øpaire, the true pre≈øage of your utter overthrow and downefall, as you bold it a common proverb amon≈øt your ≈øelves, Not to you onely this is im ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ ted, but al≈øo to your wicked confederates feared and pre≈øented in this. Kingdome. Therefore de≈øiring you all in generall for your owne profit, and willing you in His Maje≈øties name to ≈øubmit your ≈øelves, and ≈øo by con≈øequence to be converted to the holy Catholique; otherwi≈øe hide your heads under the ≈øheltring wals of Cities, &c.

div.head: A kind of a Ballad, briefly expre≈ø≈øing the pride of Engli≈øhmen in this Kingdome: an example to all men to be content with what≈øoever they have; with their ≈øpeech in the beginning of the≈øe Warres.
div.opener: To the Tune of, Ha, for my pride I mu≈øt peri≈øh.

lg.l: THe mother of your evils your ≈øouls will receive,
Hither you came ≈øurely us poore to deceive,
But ≈øuch a good token to you we will ≈øend
That ≈øoonly will teach you your lives to amend,
Your God ‚Ä¢ ars and Gamers, you rich that are mo≈øt,
Your wives and children ≈øhall pay for th ‚Ä¢ ro≈øt.
Our anger weel write in blood of your men,
And bravely weel tune it in cries of women.
Your faith you have ≈øold for pottage and bread.
In che≈øe your ≈øermons and ≈øongs you have read,
Your deeds in de≈øpaire: I need not to tell
The portent of your downfall, you know it full well:
Our ≈øouldiers and male men are valiant and ≈øtout,
Our women and female are faire and devout,
Our riches were Heaven, and you were the God,
And ≈øo we permitted untill you were ≈øod.
From Ireland to England, but what to doe there?
Your pride and pre≈øumption not kept any where.
From England your ≈øuccour I hardly beleeve,
Will come long longed ≈øuch rogues to relieve,
Your King you have bani≈øhed, and de≈øpi≈øed the Crowne,
But ≈øurely beleeve me your pride weel pull down.
Linckt in your Saddles a Hor≈øe you ride,
The ≈øight of us Iri≈øh you dare not abide.
Away good man, good ma≈øters away,
On yonder great Hill are a hundred this day.
I vow and prote≈øt good Go≈ø≈øip tis well,
To old Ma≈øter Langthon this wonder weel tell.
And ≈øtumbling and ≈øtambling away they do trot
Their wives being weake to hang the black pot.
The day you ≈øhall cur≈øe when fir≈øt you begun,
And ≈øay with your ≈øelves our race we have run.
With Gentlemens murder our minds were content,
But fainting in heart, we lately repent.
In Corke my Lord Pre≈øident ≈øhunneth the field,
His ≈øouldiers in trea≈øon from harme to ≈øhield.
Of Engli≈øh ba≈øtards in Bandon a crew,
In pri≈øon enclo≈øed for death is their due,
In Warlike affaires mong≈øt all the re≈øt,
William Hull Crookbackd accounted the be≈øt.
The chiefe to in≈øtruct to march with a rope,
In order of hanging, grant Je≈øu that ≈øcope.
Long time by mi≈ø-fortune we were your poore ≈ølaves,
You dancing in Courts, we mourning in Caves,
In ≈øome of our Lands, of our buildings of all,
When we ≈øhould our ≈øelves you Lords we did call;
But being too much over-ma≈øtered by pride
At you and your folly we ≈øcoffe and deride.
For when the beginning of the Rebels began;
From one to another they oftentimes ran,
Prethee our Dermon come hither I ≈øay,
And tell me from market what heard you this day,
In troth good ma≈øter of help is no way,
But that we mu≈øt peri≈øh and wholly decay.
Why ≈øo? our Dermon, you make me to fret,
My limbs are trembling; on feare they are ≈øet
In Bandon proclaimed and fully ≈øet forth,
That many Rebels keep campes in the Norch.
The≈øe news amazd them when fir≈øt he did blaze,
That the ‚Ä¢ were undone and in a bad ca≈øe
Through feare and di≈øpaire in Cities they heape,
The fruit of their mi≈øcheifes by dying to reape.
Good wife take ≈øome Bacon and bread, do not want,
I rather ≈øhould peri≈øh than that ≈øhould be ≈øcant.
Their Cows and their Oxen we took for the rent,
And they with the pox for the Divell are ≈øent.
Weel hunt William Sintleger like a broune Fox,
And you Lewis Boyle goe ≈øhrub with a pox,
My Lord of Barrimore go charge to the Beefe;
In faith by your Kin≈ømen an arrant great thiefe.
By riches ill gotten preferment they gained,
They like to be killed by them di≈ødained.
Your Statutes not ≈øetled on any ≈øure ground.
Your wealth did augment, and others confound.
Your fa≈øhions are hand≈øome, compleat I confe≈ø≈øe,
But all being curious your fayth did oppre≈ø≈øe.
But whether to kill them tis doubtfull to ≈øay,
Or el≈øe to ≈øhip them and ≈øend them away.

div.head: A Letter ≈øent from Colonell Goring to His Maje≈øty.
div.p: AS it is my duty, according to Your Maje≈øties commands, I have en≈øured this Fort for Your Maje≈øtie, and will ≈øacrifice my life in Your ≈øervice; The Ca≈øtle of Portland hath in like manner ≈øurrendered; ≈øo that if we be beleagured, we may notwith≈øtanding be ≈øupplied out of Your Maje≈øties fertile Iland, not doubting to cut off all ob≈øtacles to the contrary. Sir, we lie neere Your furious adver≈øaries, who we now expect daily, therefore in my opinion your be≈øt de≈øigne will be to draw what Forces you can, or the greate≈øt part thereof well appointed with Ammunition and provi≈øion towards () and there incamp where you ≈øhall ≈øee the flower of your Engli≈øh Chivalry repaire to Your Maje≈øty, and this will divert their Forces, yet I leave the≈øe con≈øiderations to the more ≈øolid judgments of Your Maje≈øty, and your Councell of War, Your Maje≈øties Fly-boat is returned with good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe I hope of their la≈øt voyage, as I under≈øtand by Your Maje≈øties intelligencer, I would not pre≈øume to open the packets, yet I had a copy of the Contents ab≈øtracted which puts me in a good hope of ≈øuch auxiliarys as by divine a≈ø≈øi≈øtance ≈øhall inthronize Your Maje≈øty againe, Charles the fir≈øt by Gods a≈ø≈øi≈øtance the mo≈øt pui≈ø≈øant Monarch of any Prince that ever ≈øwayd the Scepter in the≈øe Occidentall Europian Iles in de≈øpight and maugre all antimonarchi≈øts, for which end the prayers and endeavours of your Maje≈øties mo≈øt humble and dutifull Subject and ≈øervant ≈øhall ever be intendent at your Maje≈øties ≈øacred feet,
